S2.T1.caption: Table 1: Summary of related work.
S2.T1.table:
Area Key Differences
Predict-then-optimize Full vs. bandit feedback
Contextual bandits Sequential/adaptive vs. batch/one-shot
Causal ML/CATE estimation Estimator accuracy vs. regret minimization
Learning to rank Permutation vs. single item as output
references: Table 1 summarizes the most closely related literature areas. Below, we discuss them in more detail.

references:
As this dataset is semi-synthetic, the counterfactual outcome is given and so regret can be calculated straightforwardly. Table 2 shows the performance of the learners compared against the model trained with the ESR loss. We see that the ESR loss-trained model handily outperforms the other metalearners in regret. Table 2 also shows the regret incurred when varying <math alttext="k" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S6.SS1.p3.1.m1.1">

As this dataset is semi-synthetic, the counterfactual outcome is given and so regret can be calculated straightforwardly. Table 2 shows the performance of the learners compared against the model trained with the ESR loss. We see that the ESR loss-trained model handily outperforms the other metalearners in regret. S6.T3.caption: Table 3: CTR (95% CI) for ESR Loss Trained NN vs. other offline contextual bandit methods. The mean CTR for each day is highest for the model trained on the ESR loss. The performance improvement is statistically significant over all ten days.

references: Table 3 and Figure 2 summarize the results. Across all days the model trained on the ESR loss has higher mean CTR than the other methods, and its overall CTR is statistically significantly higher. This suggests that the model trained on the ESR loss is indeed doing a better job of capturing the dependence of the click-through rate on the article choice.
